title: Eye Cancer | Retinoblastoma | MedlinePlus
content:
**Eye Cancer**

Cancer of the eye is uncommon. It can affect the outer parts of the eye, such as the eyelid, which are made up of muscles, skin and nerves. If the cancer starts inside the eyeball it's called intraocular cancer.

**Types of Intraocular Cancers in Adults:**

* Melanoma
* Lymphoma

**Most Common Eye Cancer in Children:**

Retinoblastoma, which starts in the cells of the retina.

**How Cancer Spreads to the Eye:**

Cancer can also spread to the eye from other parts of the body.

**Treatment for Eye Cancer:**

Treatment varies by the type and by how advanced it is. It may include:

* Surgery
* Radiation therapy
* Freezing or heat therapy
* Laser therapy

**Learn More:**

For more information on eye cancer, including symptoms, diagnosis, prevention, treatments, and living with eye cancer, see the links below.

* General Information about Intraocular (Uveal) Melanoma  (National Cancer Institute)
* Also in Spanish
* General Information about Retinoblastoma  (National Cancer Institute)
* Also in Spanish
* What Is Eye Cancer? (American Cancer Society)

**Related Issues:**

Nevus (Eye Freckle) (American Academy of Ophthalmology)
Also in Spanish

**Genetics:**

Retinoblastoma: MedlinePlus Genetics  (National Library of Medicine)

**Statistics and Research:**

What's New In Eye Cancer Research and Treatment? (American Cancer Society)
ClinicalTrials.gov: Eye Neoplasms  (National Institutes of Health)
ClinicalTrials.gov: Retinoblastoma  (National Institutes of Health)
References and abstracts from MEDLINE/PubMed (National Library of Medicine)

**Find an Expert:**

American Cancer Society 
American Foundation for the Blind 
Choosing a Cancer Doctor (American Cancer Society)
Also in Spanish
Find an Ophthalmologist (American Academy of Ophthalmology)
Also in Spanish

---

**Eye Cancer**

Eye cancer, also known as intraocular or uveal melanoma, is a type of cancer that affects the eye. It can occur in adults and children, although it is more common in adults.

**Types of Eye Cancer**

There are two main types of eye cancer:

*   **Retinoblastoma**: This is the most common type of eye cancer in children, accounting for about 80% of all cases. It starts in the cells of the retina and can spread to other parts of the body.
*   **Intraocular (Uveal) Melanoma**: This type of cancer affects the pigment-producing cells in the eye and is more common in adults.

**Symptoms**

The symptoms of eye cancer can vary depending on the type and location of the tumor. Some common symptoms include:

*   **Vision problems**: Blurred vision, double vision, or loss of vision
*   **Eye pain**: Pain or discomfort in the eye
*   **Redness and swelling**: Redness and swelling of the eye or eyelid
*   **Changes in the pupil**: Changes in the size or shape of the pupil

**Diagnosis**

Diagnosing eye cancer typically involves a combination of physical examination, imaging tests, and laboratory tests. Some common diagnostic tools include:

*   **Dilating eye drops**: These are used to enlarge the pupils and allow for a more thorough examination of the inside of the eye.
*   **Ultrasound**: This test uses sound waves to create images of the eye and detect any abnormalities.
*   **Biopsy**: A sample of tissue is removed from the eye and examined under a microscope.

**Treatment**

The treatment for eye cancer depends on the type and location of the tumor, as well as the patient's overall health. Some common treatments include:

*   **Surgery**: Removing the tumor or affected part of the eye
*   **Radiation therapy**: Using high-energy rays to kill cancer cells
*   **Freezing or heat therapy**: Freezing or heating the tumor to destroy it
*   **Laser therapy**: Using a laser to destroy the tumor

**Prevention and Risk Factors**

While there is no surefire way to prevent eye cancer, some risk factors can increase the likelihood of developing the disease. These include:

*   **Family history**: Having a family history of eye cancer or other types of cancer
*   **Genetic mutations**: Certain genetic mutations, such as those associated with retinoblastoma
*   **Exposure to radiation**: Exposure to high levels of radiation, particularly in childhood

**Living With Eye Cancer**

Living with eye cancer can be challenging, but there are ways to manage the disease and maintain quality of life. Some tips include:

*   **Following treatment plans**: Adhering to treatment recommendations and attending follow-up appointments
*   **Practicing self-care**: Engaging in activities that promote physical and emotional well-being
*   **Seeking support**: Connecting with others who have experienced eye cancer or other types of cancer

**Statistics and Research**

Eye cancer is a relatively rare disease, but it can have a significant impact on those affected. Some statistics include:

*   **Incidence rates**: According to the American Cancer Society, approximately 2,500 new cases of eye cancer are diagnosed each year in the United States.
*   **Survival rates**: The five-year survival rate for eye cancer is around 80%, although this can vary depending on the type and stage of the disease.

**Clinical Trials**

Researchers are continually working to improve our understanding of eye cancer and develop more effective treatments. Some ongoing clinical trials include:

*   **Investigating new treatments**: Evaluating the safety and efficacy of novel therapies, such as immunotherapy or targeted therapy
*   **Exploring combination therapies**: Investigating the use of multiple treatments in conjunction with one another

**Journal Articles**

Researchers have published numerous studies on eye cancer, shedding light on various aspects of the disease. Some recent articles include:

*   **Epidemiology of oculo-orbital tumours in Malawian children**: A 10-year review of cases and outcomes
*   **Tumor immune microenvironment in adenoid cystic carcinoma of the lacrimal gland**: An investigation into the molecular mechanisms underlying this rare type of cancer
*   **Artificial intelligence to enhance the diagnosis of ocular surface squamous neoplasia**: A study exploring the potential of AI-powered diagnostic tools

**Find an Expert**

If you or a loved one has been diagnosed with eye cancer, it's essential to find a qualified healthcare provider who can provide guidance and support. Some resources include:

*   **American Cancer Society**: A comprehensive resource for patients and families affected by cancer
*   **American Academy of Ophthalmology**: A professional organization dedicated to advancing the field of ophthalmology
*   **National Eye Institute**: A government agency focused on funding research and providing education related to eye health and disease

---

**Eye Cancer**

\n\n**Retinoblastoma**

*   A rare form of eye cancer that primarily affects children under the age of 5
*   It starts in the retina, the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye
*   If left untreated, retinoblastoma can cause vision loss or even blindness

\n\n**MedlinePlus Links**

MedlinePlus links to health information from the National Institutes of Health and other federal government agencies. MedlinePlus also links to health information from non-government Web sites.

\n\n**Related Health Topics**

*   **Eye Diseases**: A collection of articles on various eye diseases, including cataracts, glaucoma, and age-related macular degeneration
*   **Eyelid Disorders**: Information on conditions affecting the eyelids, such as blepharitis and eyelid cancer

\n\n**National Institutes of Health**

The primary NIH organization for research on Eye Cancer is the National Cancer Institute.

title: Eye Care | Vision Care | MedlinePlus
content:
**Eye Care**

Also called: Eye health, Eye safety

**Basics**

Your eyes are an important part of your health. Most people rely on their eyes to see and make sense of the world around them. But some eye diseases can lead to vision loss, so it is important to identify and treat eye diseases as early as possible.

**Eye Care Tips**

There are things you can do to help keep your eyes healthy and make sure you are seeing your best:

*   Eat a healthy, balanced diet.
*   Maintain a healthy weight.
*   Get regular exercise.
*   Wear sunglasses that block out 99 to 100% of both UV-A and UV-B radiation.
*   Wear protective eye wear when playing certain sports, working in jobs such as factory work and construction, and doing repairs or projects in your home.
*   Avoid smoking.
*   Know your family medical history.
*   Know your other risk factors.
*   If you wear contacts, take steps to prevent eye infections.

**Eye Tests and Exams**

Everyone needs to have their eyesight tested to check for vision and eye problems. Children usually have vision screening in school or at their health care provider's office during a checkup. Adults may also get vision screenings during their checkups. But many adults need more than a vision screening. They need a comprehensive dilated eye exam.

**Getting Comprehensive Dilated Eye Exams**

The exams are the only way to detect these diseases in their early stages, when they are easier to treat. The exam includes several tests:

*   A visual field test to measure your side (peripheral) vision.
*   A visual acuity test, where you read an eye chart about 20 feet away, to check on how well you see at various distances
*   Tonometry, which measures your eye's interior pressure. It helps to detect glaucoma.
*   Dilation, which involves getting eye drops that dilate (widen) your pupils.

**Start Here**

Eye Safety at Home (Prevent Blindness America)
Healthy Living, Healthy Vision (Prevent Blindness America)
Keep Your Eyes Healthy  (National Eye Institute)

How Do Smoking and Vaping Damage the Eyes? (American Academy of Ophthalmology)
Protect Your Eyes from Sun Damage  (National Institutes of Health)

**Journal Articles**

References and abstracts from MEDLINE/PubMed (National Library of Medicine)
Article: Modulation of TTR gene expression in the eye using modified siRNAs. 
Article: SS-OCT-based ocular biometric characteristics of patients with nuclear cataract. 
Article: Ocular markers of microangiopathy and their possible association with cardiovascular risk...

---

**Eye Care**

Your eyes are an important part of your health. Most people rely on their eyes to see and make sense of the world around them. But some eye diseases can lead to vision loss, so it is important to identify and treat eye diseases as early as possible. You should get your eyes checked as often as your health care provider recommends it, or if you have any new vision problems. And just as it is important to keep your body healthy, you also need to keep your eyes healthy.

**Eye Care Tips**

There are things you can do to help keep your eyes healthy and make sure you are seeing your best:

*   Eat a healthy, balanced diet. Your diet should include plenty of fruits and vegetables, especially deep yellow and green leafy vegetables. Eating fish high in omega-3 fatty acids, such as salmon, tuna, and halibut can also help your eyes.
*   Maintain a healthy weight. Being overweight or having obesity increases your risk of developing diabetes. Having diabetes puts you at higher risk of getting diabetic retinopathy or glaucoma.
*   Get regular exercise. Exercise may help to prevent or control diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol. These diseases can lead to some eye or vision problems. So if you exercise regularly, you can lower your risk of getting these eye and vision problems.
*   Wear sunglasses. Sun exposure can damage your eyes and raise your risk of cataracts and age-related macular degeneration. Protect your eyes by using sunglasses that block out 99 to 100% of both UV-A and UV-B radiation.
*   Wear protective eye wear. To prevent eye injuries, you need eye protection when playing certain sports, working in jobs such as factory work and construction, and doing repairs or projects in your home.
*   Avoid smoking. Smoking increases the risk of developing age-related eye diseases such as macular degeneration and cataracts and can damage the optic nerve.
*   Know your family medical history. Some eye diseases are inherited, so it is important to find out whether anyone in your family has had them. This can help you determine if you are at higher risk of developing an eye disease.
*   Know your other risk factors. As you get older, you are at higher risk of developing age-related eye diseases and conditions. It is important to know your risk factors because you may be able to lower your risk by changing some behaviors.
*   If you wear contacts, take steps to prevent eye infections. Wash your hands well before you put in or take out your contact lenses. Also follow the instructions on how to properly clean them, and replace them when needed.
*   Give your eyes a rest. If you spend a lot of time using a computer, you can forget to blink your eyes and your eyes can get tired. To reduce eyestrain, try the 20-20-20 rule: Every 20 minutes, look away about 20 feet in front of you for 20 seconds.

**Eye Tests and Exams**

Everyone needs to have their eyesight tested to check for vision and eye problems. Children usually have vision screening in school or at their health care provider's office during a checkup. Adults may also get vision screenings during their checkups. But many adults need more than a vision screening. They need a comprehensive dilated eye exam.

Getting comprehensive dilated eye exams is especially important because some eye diseases may not have warning signs. The exams are the only way to detect these diseases in their early stages, when they are easier to treat.

The exam includes several tests:

*   A visual field test to measure your side (peripheral) vision. A loss of peripheral vision may be a sign of glaucoma.
*   A visual acuity test, where you read an eye chart about 20 feet away, to check on how well you see at various distances
*   Tonometry, which measures your eye's interior pressure. It helps to detect glaucoma.
*   Dilation, which involves getting eye drops that dilate (widen) your pupils. This allows more light to enter the eye. Your eye care provider examines your eyes using a special magnifying lens. This provides a clear view of important tissues at the back of your eye, including the retina, macula, and optic nerve.

If you have a refractive error and are going to need glasses or contacts, then you will also have a refraction test. When you have this test, you look through a device that has lenses of different strengths to help your eye care professional figure out which lenses will give you the clearest vision.

At what age you should start getting these exams and how often you need them depends on many factors. They include your age, race, and overall health. For example, if you are African American, you are at higher risk of glaucoma and you need to start getting the exams earlier. If you have diabetes, you should get an exam every year. Check with your health care provider about if and when you need these exams.

---

**Eye Care**

**Start Here**

*   **Overall Health**: Taking care of your overall health is crucial for maintaining good eye health. For example, if you are African American, you are at higher risk of glaucoma and you need to start getting the exams earlier. If you have diabetes, you should get an exam every year.
*   **Prevent Blindness America**: Check with your health care provider about if and when you need these exams.

**Diagnosis and Tests**

*   **Eye Exam and Vision Testing Basics**: An eye exam is a thorough check of the eyes to detect any problems. It involves a series of tests to assess vision, eye alignment, and other aspects of eye health.
*   **Get a Dilated Eye Exam**: A dilated eye exam is a comprehensive eye examination that involves the use of special drops to dilate the pupils, allowing for a more thorough inspection of the eyes.
*   **Get an Eye Disease Screening at 40**: Regular eye exams are essential for detecting eye diseases early on. The American Academy of Ophthalmology recommends getting an eye disease screening at age 40.

**Prevention and Risk Factors**

*   **Diet and Nutrition**: A healthy diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins is essential for maintaining good eye health.
*   **Eye Protection**: Wearing protective eyewear can help prevent eye injuries. This includes safety glasses, goggles, or other forms of protective eyewear.

**Treatments and Therapies**

*   **Tired, Achy Eyes? Finding Relief for Eye Discomfort**: If you're experiencing tired, achy eyes, there are several remedies that may provide relief. These include applying a warm compress to the eyes, using artificial tears to lubricate the eyes, or taking breaks to rest the eyes.

**Related Issues**

*   **Difference Between an Ophthalmologist, Optometrist, and Optician**: Understanding the difference between an ophthalmologist, optometrist, and optician is crucial for making informed decisions about eye care.
*   **Foods for Eye Health**: Certain foods are rich in nutrients that can help promote eye health. These include leafy greens like spinach and kale, fatty fish like salmon, and nuts like almonds.

**Specifics**

*   **Fireworks Eye Safety**: When handling fireworks, it's essential to take precautions to protect your eyes from potential hazards.
*   **How Do Smoking and Vaping Damage the Eyes?**: Smoking and vaping can cause significant damage to the eyes, including an increased risk of cataracts, age-related macular degeneration, and other eye problems.

**Journal Articles**

*   **Modulation of TTR gene expression in the eye using modified siRNAs.**
*   **SS-OCT-based ocular biometric characteristics of patients with nuclear cataract.**
*   **Ocular markers of microangiopathy and their possible association with cardiovascular risk...**

**Children**

*   **About the Eye**: The human eye is a complex and fascinating organ that plays a crucial role in our overall health and well-being.
*   **First Aid Tips**: In case of an eye injury, it's essential to seek medical attention immediately. However, there are some basic first aid tips that can help alleviate discomfort until proper treatment can be administered.

**Older Adults**

*   **Aging and Your Eyes**: As we age, our eyes undergo significant changes that can impact our vision and overall health.
*   **Your Aging Eyes: How You See as Time Goes By**: Understanding how our eyes change with age is crucial for maintaining good eye health and preventing age-related eye problems.

**Topic Image**

**National Institutes of Health**

*   **The primary NIH organization for research on Eye Care is the National Eye Institute**

**Disclaimers**

title: Eye Diseases | Glaucoma | MedlinePlus
content:
**Eye Diseases**

Even if your eyes feel healthy, you could have a problem and not know it. That's why regular eye exams are so important. Refractive errors are the most common type of vision problem that makes it hard to see clearly. But some eye conditions or diseases don't have any symptoms and can lead to a permanent loss of vision.

Some common eye diseases and conditions include:

*   Cataracts, which happens when the clear lens in the front of your eye becomes cloudy.
*   Optic nerve disorders, which includes glaucoma.
*   Retinal disorders, which are problems with the nerve layer at the back of your eye.
*   Macular degeneration, which is a disease that destroys your sharp, central vision.
*   Diabetic eye problems, which can cause vision loss and blindness.
*   Conjunctivitis, which is an infection also known as pink eye.

**Symptoms**

Some eye conditions and diseases do not always have symptoms. Early detection through a comprehensive dilated eye exam could help your eye care provider detect diseases in the early stages. Proper treatment could help slow or prevent vision loss.

Get regular eye exams and call your eye care professional right away if you notice any of these symptoms:

*   A sudden change in vision
*   Everything looks dim
*   Flashes of light
*   Eye pain
*   Double vision
*   Fluid coming from your eye
*   Inflammation (swelling)

**Who is more likely to develop eye diseases?**

Getting older increases your risk of some eye diseases. Other things that may put you at a higher risk of some eye diseases can include if you:

*   Are overweight or obese
*   Have a family history of eye disease
*   Are African American, Hispanic, or Native American
*   Have certain health conditions such as Diabetic eye problems, or high blood pressure

**What are the treatments for eye diseases?**

Treatment may depend on the eye condition or disease but can include:

*   A new prescription for eyeglasses or contacts
*   Use of bright lights or magnifying lenses for reading and other activities
*   Medicines
*   Prescription eye drops or ointments
*   Laser treatment
*   Surgery

Depending on your eye condition or disease, treatment may slow vision loss but may not restore vision. Talk to your provider about what treatment is best for you.

**Can eye diseases be prevented?**

Your best defense is to have regular checkups. Be sure to tell your provider if any eye diseases run in your family.

You can also help take care of your vision by making lifestyle changes to lower your risk of health conditions that can cause vision problems. This could include:

*   Protecting your eyes from the sun
*   Wearing protective eyewear while using tools or playing certain sports
*   Getting regular physical activity
*   Staying at a healthy weight
*   Quitting smoking (or not starting)
*   Eating a healthy diet

---

**Eye Diseases**

Even if your eyes feel healthy, you could have a problem and not know it. That's why regular eye exams are so important.

**Common Eye Diseases and Conditions**

Some common eye diseases and conditions include:

*   Cataracts, which happens when the clear lens in the front of your eye becomes cloudy.
*   Optic nerve disorders, which includes glaucoma. Glaucoma usually happens when the fluid pressure inside your eyes slowly rises.
*   Retinal disorders, which are problems with the nerve layer at the back of your eye.
*   Macular degeneration, which is a disease that destroys your sharp, central vision.
*   Diabetic eye problems, which can cause vision loss and blindness.
*   Conjunctivitis, which is an infection also known as pink eye. It can cause pink or red itchy eyes.

**Symptoms of Eye Diseases**

Some eye conditions and diseases do not always have symptoms. Early detection through a comprehensive dilated eye exam could help your eye care provider detect diseases in the early stages. Proper treatment could help slow or prevent vision loss.

Get regular eye exams and call your eye care professional right away if you notice any of these symptoms:

*   A sudden change in vision
*   Everything looks dim
*   Flashes of light
*   Eye pain
*   Double vision
*   Fluid coming from your eye
*   Inflammation (swelling)

**Who is More Likely to Develop Eye Diseases?**

Getting older increases your risk of some eye diseases. Other things that may put you at a higher risk of some eye diseases can include if you:

*   Are overweight or obese
*   Have a family history of eye disease
*   Are African American, Hispanic, or Native American
*   Have certain health conditions such as Diabetic eye problems, or high blood pressure

**Treatments for Eye Diseases**

Treatment may depend on the eye condition or disease but can include:

*   A new prescription for eyeglasses or contacts
*   Use of bright lights or magnifying lenses for reading and other activities
*   Medicines
*   Prescription eye drops or ointments
*   Laser treatment
*   Surgery

Depending on your eye condition or disease, treatment may slow vision loss but may not restore vision. Talk to your provider about what treatment is best for you.

**Can Eye Diseases be Prevented?**

Your best defense is to have regular checkups. Be sure to tell your provider if any eye diseases run in your family.

You can also help take care of your vision by making lifestyle changes to lower your risk of health conditions that can cause vision problems. This could include by:

*   Protecting your eyes from the sun
*   Wearing protective eyewear while using tools or playing certain sports
*   Getting regular physical activity
*   Staying at a healthy weight
*   Quitting smoking (or not starting)
*   Eating a healthy diet

---

**Eye Diseases**

Even if your eyes feel healthy, you could have a problem and not know it. That's why regular eye exams are so important.

**Refractive Errors**

The most common type of vision problem that makes it hard to see clearly.

**Common Eye Diseases and Conditions**

Some eye conditions and diseases do not always have symptoms. Early detection through a comprehensive dilated eye exam could help your eye care provider detect diseases in the early stages. Proper treatment could help slow or prevent vision loss.

**Get Regular Eye Exams**

Get regular eye exams and call your eye care professional right away if you notice any of these symptoms:

* Getting older increases your risk of some eye diseases.
* Other things that may put you at a higher risk of some eye diseases can include:
	+ Family history of certain eye conditions
	+ Certain medical conditions, such as diabetes or high blood pressure

**Treatment**

Treatment may depend on the eye condition or disease but can include:

* Medications to reduce inflammation or slow vision loss
* Surgery to repair or remove damaged tissue
* Laser therapy to treat certain conditions
* Other treatments, such as eye drops or ointments, to help manage symptoms

**Prevention and Risk Factors**

You can also help take care of your vision by making lifestyle changes to lower your risk of health conditions that can cause vision problems. This could include:

* Wearing protective eyewear while using tools or playing certain sports

**Living With Eye Diseases**

Your best defense is to have regular checkups. Be sure to tell your provider if any eye diseases run in your family.

\n\n

* **Anisocoria**: a condition where the pupils are unequal in size
* **Choroidal dystrophies**: a group of genetic disorders that affect the choroid, a layer of tissue between the sclera and retina
* **Coloboma of the iris**: a congenital defect in the iris caused by incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure
* **Episcleritis**: inflammation of the episcleral tissue, which is the thin layer of connective tissue that surrounds the sclera
* **Eye and orbit ultrasound**: an imaging test that uses high-frequency sound waves to create images of the eye and surrounding tissues
* **Eye burning - itching and discharge**: a symptom characterized by a sensation of burning or itching in the eye accompanied by a discharge
* **Eye pain**: a symptom characterized by discomfort or pain in the eye
* **Eye redness**: a symptom characterized by inflammation or discoloration of the conjunctiva, which is the thin membrane that covers the white part of the eye
* **Eyes - bulging**: a condition where the eyes protrude from their sockets due to increased pressure within the orbit

\n\n

**Related Health Topics**

* **Amblyopia**: a vision disorder characterized by reduced vision in one eye, often caused by anisometropia or strabismus
* **Cataract**: a clouding of the lens in the eye that can cause vision loss
* **Color Blindness**: a condition where a person has difficulty perceiving certain colors due to a genetic mutation
* **Corneal Disorders**: a group of conditions that affect the cornea, including keratitis and corneal ulcers
* **Diabetic Eye Problems**: a group of complications that can arise from diabetes, including diabetic retinopathy and cataracts
* **Eye Cancer**: a type of cancer that affects the eye or surrounding tissues
* **Eye Care**: general information on maintaining good eye health
* **Eye Infections**: a group of infections that affect the eye, including conjunctivitis and keratitis
* **Eye Injuries**: a group of injuries that can affect the eye, including trauma and foreign body ingestion
* **Eye Movement Disorders**: a group of conditions that affect the movement of the eyes, including nystagmus and strabismus
* **Eye Wear**: information on corrective eyewear, including glasses and contact lenses
* **Eyelid Disorders**: a group of conditions that affect the eyelids, including blepharitis and entropion
* **Macular Degeneration**: a condition where the macula, which is the part of the retina responsible for central vision, deteriorates over time
* **Optic Nerve Disorders**: a group of conditions that affect the optic nerve, including glaucoma and optic neuritis
* **Pink Eye**: a common infection of the conjunctiva characterized by redness, itching, and discharge
* **Refractive Errors**: a group of vision disorders caused by irregularities in the shape of the cornea or lens
* **Retinal Detachment**: a condition where the retina separates from the underlying tissue
* **Retinal Disorders**: a group of conditions that affect the retina, including diabetic retinopathy and age-related macular degeneration
* **Tears**: a symptom characterized by excessive tearing or dryness in the eye
* **Vision Impairment and Blindness**: general information on vision loss and its causes

\n\n

**National Institutes of Health**

The primary NIH organization for research on Eye Diseases is the National Eye Institute.

title: Eye Infections | Conjunctivitis | Stye | MedlinePlus
content:
**Eye Infections**

Your eyes can get infections from bacteria, fungi, or viruses. Eye infections can occur in different parts of the eye and can affect just one eye or both.

**Common Eye Infections**

Two common eye infections are:

* **Conjunctivitis** - also known as pink eye. Conjunctivitis is often due to an infection. Children frequently get it, and it is very contagious.
* **Stye** - a bump on the eyelid that happens when bacteria from your skin get into the hair follicle of an eyelash.

**Symptoms of Eye Infections**

Symptoms of eye infections may include:

* Redness
* Itching
* Swelling
* Discharge
* Pain
* Problems with vision

**Treatment of Eye Infections**

Treatment depends on the cause of the infection and may include:

* Compresses
* Eye drops
* Creams
* Antibiotics

---

**Eye Infections | Conjunctivitis | Stye**

Treatment depends on the cause of the infection and may include compresses, eye drops, creams, or antibiotics.

**Eye Infections**

\n\n**Conjunctivitis, Stye, and Other Eye Problems**

* **Blepharitis**: inflammation of the eyelids
* **CMV retinitis**: a viral infection of the retina
* **Corneal ulcers and infections**: bacterial or fungal infections of the cornea
* **Dacryoadenitis**: inflammation of the tear gland
* **Endophthalmitis**: a severe infection of the inner eye
* **Eye burning - itching and discharge**: symptoms of conjunctivitis or other eye infections
* **Eye redness**: a symptom of various eye conditions, including conjunctivitis and blepharitis
* **Meibomianitis**: inflammation of the meibomian glands
* **Orbital cellulitis**: a bacterial infection of the tissues around the eye
* **Parinaud oculoglandular syndrome**: a rare condition characterized by swelling of the eyelid and conjunctiva

title: Eye Injury | MedlinePlus
content:
**Eye Injuries**

**Basics**

The structure of your face helps protect your eyes from injury. Still, injuries can damage your eye, sometimes severely enough that you could lose your vision. Most eye injuries are preventable. If you play sports or work in certain jobs, you may need protection.

**Symptoms**

The most common type of injury happens when something irritates the outer surface of your eye. Certain jobs such as industrial jobs or hobbies such as carpentry make this type of injury more likely. It's also more likely if you wear contact lenses.

**Prevention and Risk Factors**

Chemicals or heat can burn your eyes. With chemicals, the pain may cause you to close your eyes. This traps the irritant next to the eye and may cause more damage. You should wash out your eye right away while you wait for medical help.

**Treatments and Therapies**

**Eye Injury**

Most eye injuries are preventable. If you play sports or work in certain jobs, you may need protection.

**Symptoms**

* Eye irritation
* Chemical burns
* Heat burns

**Prevention and Risk Factors**

* Certain jobs such as industrial jobs or hobbies such as carpentry make this type of injury more likely.
* Wearing contact lenses also increases the risk.
* Playing sports or working in certain jobs may require protective eyewear.

**Treatments and Therapies**

* Washing out your eye with water if you get a chemical splash
* Using dilating eye drops for diagnosis
* Enucleation (removal of the eyeball) in severe cases

**Specifics**

* Black Eye: a bruise on the eyelid or under the eyebrow
* Blowout Fracture: a fracture of the bones around the eye socket
* Corneal Abrasions: scratches on the cornea, the clear dome covering the front of the eye
* Corneal Laceration: a cut in the cornea
* Eye Safety at Home: preventing eye injuries with protective eyewear and proper use of household chemicals
* Macular Pucker: a condition where the macula, the part of the retina responsible for central vision, becomes scarred
* Prevent Workplace Eye Injuries: using protective eyewear and following safety protocols in the workplace
* What Is Hyphema?: bleeding into the vitreous humor, the clear gel-like substance inside the eyeball

**Images**

* Corneal Abrasion: a scratch on the cornea
* Corneal Foreign Body: an object embedded in the cornea

title: Eye Movement Disorders | Nystagmus | Strabismus | MedlinePlus
content:
**Eye Movement Disorders**

When you look at an object, you're using several muscles to move both eyes to focus on it. If you have a problem with the muscles, the eyes don't work properly.

There are many kinds of eye movement disorders. Two common ones are:

* **Strabismus**: a disorder in which the two eyes don't line up in the same direction. This results in "crossed eyes" or "walleye."
* **Nystagmus**: fast, uncontrollable movements of the eyes, sometimes called "dancing eyes"

**Diagnosis and Tests**

* **Strabismus Measurements**: a test used to measure the angle of strabismus
* **Videonystagmography (VNG)**: a test used to diagnose nystagmus
* **Vision Screening**: a test used to detect vision problems in children

**Treatments and Therapies**

* **Anesthesia for Adults Having Eye Surgery**: anesthesia used during eye surgery
* **Eye muscle repair**: surgical procedure to repair damaged eye muscles
* **Prisms**: corrective lenses used to treat strabismus
* **Strabismus Surgery**: surgical procedure to correct strabismus

**Related Issues**

* **Abnormal Head Position**: a condition where the head is held in an abnormal position due to strabismus
* **Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP)**: a rare neurological disorder that can cause eye movement problems

**Specifics**

* **Accommodative Esotropia**: a type of strabismus caused by accommodative esotropia
* **Brown Syndrome**: a rare condition that affects the movement of the eyes
* **Conjugate Gaze Palsies**: a condition where there is weakness or paralysis of one or more eye muscles
* **Duane Syndrome**: a congenital disorder that affects the movement of the eyes

**Genetics**

* **About Duane Syndrome**: information about Duane syndrome and its genetic causes
* **Congenital fibrosis of the extraocular muscles**: a rare condition that affects the movement of the eyes due to genetic mutations
* **Horizontal gaze palsy with progressive scoliosis**: a rare condition that affects the movement of the eyes due to genetic mutations

**Statistics and Research**

* **Eye Health Data and Statistics**: statistics about eye health in the United States
* **Clinical Trials**: information about clinical trials related to eye movement disorders
* **Journal Articles**: references and abstracts from MEDLINE/PubMed about eye movement disorders

---

**Eye Movement Disorders**

An eye movement disorder is a problem with the way your eyes move. There are several types of eye movement disorders, including:

* **Strabismus**: an eye movement disorder where the two eyes don't line up in the same direction, resulting in "crossed eyes" or "walleye."
* **Nystagmus**: fast, uncontrollable movements of the eyes, sometimes called "dancing eyes"

Some eye movement disorders are present at birth, while others develop over time and may be associated with other problems, such as injuries. Treatments include glasses, patches, eye muscle exercises, and surgery.

**Causes**

When you look at an object, you're using several muscles to move both eyes to focus on it. If you have a problem with the muscles, the eyes don't work properly.

**Types of Eye Movement Disorders**

There are many kinds of eye movement disorders. Two common ones are:

* **Strabismus**: an eye movement disorder where the two eyes don't line up in the same direction, resulting in "crossed eyes" or "walleye."
* **Nystagmus**: fast, uncontrollable movements of the eyes, sometimes called "dancing eyes"

**Diagnosis and Tests**

To diagnose an eye movement disorder, your doctor may use the following tests:

* **Strabismus Measurements**: a test to measure the amount of strabismus
* **Videonystagmography (VNG)**: a test to measure nystagmus
* **Vision Screening**: a test to check for vision problems

**Treatments and Therapies**

Treatment for eye movement disorders may include:

* **Glasses**: to correct vision problems
* **Patches**: to help the eyes focus on one object at a time
* **Eye muscle exercises**: to strengthen the muscles that control eye movement
* **Surgery**: in some cases, surgery may be necessary to correct the problem

**Genetics**

Some eye movement disorders are caused by genetic mutations. Research has identified several genetic mutations that can cause eye movement disorders, including:

* **Duane Syndrome**: a rare genetic disorder that affects the muscles that control eye movement
* **Progressive external ophthalmoplegia**: a rare genetic disorder that affects the muscles that control eye movement

**Statistics and Research**

The National Eye Institute has published data on eye health statistics, including information on eye movement disorders.
